posts.cooked:
Hello! We are trying to use Pathplanner’s PathfindtoPose command, but we’re running into multiple problems. I know there is a solution for each problem, but I’m having a hard time figuring out what they are. The lineup code works perfectly in simulation (without the Apriltags), so I’m thinking it has something to do with our AprilTags and Limelight. We’re using a Kracken drivetrain and the new Limelight 4 with MegaTag2.

Problem #1: When I hit the path button, the robot drives to the default position in our switch case instead of to the tag it currently sees. We have our switch case connected to the TID value from the limelight, so for example, if it sees tag 7, it will drive to the left or right side of AprilTag 7 depending on if you hit the left or right trigger. This means our switch case isn’t updating with the correct tag. Problem #2: When we tested the lineup with the default tag in our switch case, the robot would drive away from the tag instead of towards it , or it would try to turn 180 degrees then stop when it lost sight of the tag. It is possible that our rotation2d is 180 degrees off, but our poses are definitely correct. My initial guess is that something is wrong with the Limelight Field-Space Localization or Pathplanner’s Autobuilder.

I did attempt to bypass the switch case by making a pathfind command in RobotContainer, but that ran into the same issues. Our switch case, limelight, and Pathplanner AutoBuilder are located in CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java, and the button command is in RobotContainer. I would greatly appreciate someone more experienced than me to look at our code and see if you can find any issues with our switch case or Pathplanner/Limelight configuration. Here is our code: https://github.com/team5675/2025Robot . Thank you for your help!

posts.name: James Barnes
posts.cooked:
In your limelight block, you’re passing in -19 to SetRobotOrientation. Not sure what passing that in does for the limelight. Have you looked into seeing what your robot odometry is posting? I think this could be troubleshot completely in path planner telemetry window. The telemetry window should show your robot odometry pose, as well as the pathToPose trajectory.

In your driveToPose command, there aren’t any protections to make sure an aprilTag is being seen before being ran. When you press right trigger, if your limelight can’t see a tag, the command should be printing “Warning: No valid AprilTag detected. Defaulting to A_BLUE.”.

Take a look at limelighthelpers ‘hasTarget’ boolean and find some ways to only run your driveToPose command when you can see a tag (or at least you remember the last tag you’ve seen ).

Cool solution for reef alignment, happy troubleshooting

My mistake, I thought the -19 was for the limelight pitch, but it’s actually the robot pitch which should definitely be zero. I did use Pathplanner’s telemetry window, and the button activated the path, but the robot either turned 180 degrees then stopped when it lost sight of the tag or it tried to move but was unsuccessful. The path runs perfectly in simulation, however, and here is a video showing it: https://youtu.be/ZjrR40I3IdY .

When I was troubleshooting, one of the problems I fixed was Pathplanner starting the path from (0,0) instead of the robot pose, and I fixed that by putting this.m_poseEstimator.getEstimatedPosition() in the AutoBuilder. Before, it was getState().Pose, which was always returning (0,0) instead of the current pose. Could that be the same for getState().Speeds? Could that be an issue if Speeds also returns zero? Thanks for the tip!

posts.name: James Barnes
posts.cooked:
Looks good!

Without Vision estimations re-seeding odometry, the pathToPose should work just fine on the real robot. If you wanted to, you could comment out the megatag seeding and give that a shot.

getState().Speeds should be correct.

I have ran into another issue where the limelight yaw is 180 degrees flipped. Our limelight is in the front of our robot, facing the front of the robot, and our yaw is set to zero. If I flip the yaw to 180, then the back of the robot becomes the front which is not good. Does anyone have a solution to this problem? IMG_5542 1920×1440 244 KB

IMG_5542 1920×1440 244 KB

In CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java -

Use the units class

posts.name: James Barnes
posts.cooked:
Double checked, I’m wrong, degrees is correct.

I do think the issue is specifically coming from seeding the limelight to the robot.  I see in your code that ‘limelightHelpers.setRobotOrientation’ is called quite a lot.

What’s catching my eye is that you set the camera position differently depending on if you’re red alliance or blue alliance (line 339)

I’d double check the limelight documentation. I’m used to setting the limelight position in the cameras webserver instead of in the code.

NotJames:

Without Vision estimations re-seeding odometry, the pathToPose should work just fine on the real robot.

Could you elaborate on this?  We’re using Limelight MegaPose2 to add vision measurements, so I’m wondering how that impacts Pathfinder’s Pathfind to Pose?

posts.name: James Barnes
posts.cooked:
PKopf:

Could you elaborate on this? We’re using Limelight MegaPose2 to add vision measurements, so I’m wondering how that impacts Pathfinder’s Pathfind to Pose?

There’s two Pose’s being averaged together, one from Dead-Reckoning, and the other from Vision. Adding the Vision Pose into the average corrects the Dead-Reckoning Pose which drifts over time. PathPlanner can run a path without vision. It can work just fine with the robots Dead-Reckoning Odometry.

If your drivetrains dead-reckoning Pose isn’t correct. That’s a problem. If your visions Pose isn’t correct. That’s probably a bigger problem.

Take it a step at a time. Comment out the line for adding vision measurements. Make sure the drivetrains dead reckoning is accurate. Make a path that drives the robot forward a meter, waits a second, and then back a meter. Make sure it hits the same marks ever time. This should be really close, like a few inches.

Add back in your vision, make sure that in the limelight webGUI the Pose it’s reporting is correct.

We found our issue with the incorrect yaw. When we were on the blue alliance, the robot’s yaw was correct, but when we switched to red, the yaw was off by 180 degrees. I’m not sure if there’s a better way to fix this, but we created an if statement so that if we’re on the red alliance, add 180 to the yaw periodically, and that did the trick. Is there a more efficient way to solve this problem?

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: Do you use blue always for coordinates?  IT makes it a good bit easier, though you do have to adjust your driver perspective in your drivetrain.

posts.name: James Barnes
posts.cooked:
I think what you did is an efficient/effective solution, million ways to skin a cat.

The getBotPoseEstimate_wpiBlue_MegaTag2 method is always going to provide the coordinates respective to blue origin. So, when feeding the camera position with setRobotOrientation() method, it looks like it also needs to be blue Origin relative.

I’m not used to using the setRobotOrientation() method. I’ve normally set the limelight orientation in the webgui here

image 1091×572 111 KB

image 1091×572 111 KB

image 1091×572 111 KB

How is your pathfindToPose() been performing? Have you tried with/without vision?

We have tried it with and without vision and they both perform well, but it is more accurate with vision for sure. I’m not sure why, but when I started our robot yesterday, the yaw flipped 180 degrees again, so I commented out the if(DriverStation.getAlliance().orElse(Alliance.Blue) == Alliance.Red) {             redAllianceYaw += 180;         } code and it worked again. Maybe it has something to do with our Pigeon, but I can’t explain why I sometimes need to flip the yaw 180. We are turning the robot on in the same orientation too. Is it a good idea to manually reset the Pigeon’s yaw to zero (this.getPigeon2().setYaw(0)) when the robot is turned on or will that mess with the limelight’s pose estimation if the robot isn’t facing forward?
